graph.name: Temperature
graph.title: Global Average Temperature (˚C)
graph.description: The temperature near Earth’s surface is rising: the bars show each year’s average temperature compared to the 20th century average.
graph.help:
Earth’s overall temperature has increased by 1.3°F (0.7°C) since 1900.
In the graph, average annual surface temperature is shown as the difference from the average for 1901-2000.

graph.name: CarbonDioxide
graph.title: Carbon Dioxide (ppm)
graph.description: The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has risen by 25% since 1958, and by about 40% since the Industrial Revolution.
graph.help: Atmospheric carbon dioxide has increased by about 40% since 1750. The graph shows the number of CO2 molecules per million molecules of dry air measured at Mauna Loa, Hawai'i. The black line shows monthly values; the red line shows the running average.

graph.name: SnowCover
graph.title: Spring Snow Cover (million km2)
graph.description: Snow is melting earlier: each bar shows spring snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere compared to the long-term average.
graph.help: Earlier melting of winter snow has reduced the area of land covered by snow in spring. The graph shows the area covered by snow in the Northern Hemisphere during March and April, shown as the difference from the 1971-2000 average.

verticalaxis.title: March-April Snow Cover Anomaly (million square km)

graph.name: SeaLevel
graph.title: Global Average Sea Level (mm)
graph.description: The ocean’s surface is rising: water expands as it warms, and melting of ice sheets and glaciers on land adds water to the ocean.
graph.help:
The average height of the ocean’s surface has increased by 8.25 inches (210 mm) since 1880.
The graph shows mean global sea level measured by tidal gauges since 1880 and by satellite instruments since 1993.

verticalaxis.title: Global Sea Level (mm) shown as difference from 1990

graph.name: asi
graph.title: September Arctic Sea Ice (1000 km2)
graph.description: The area covered by sea ice in the Arctic at the end of summer has shrunk by about 40% since 1979.
graph.help:
The area of the Arctic where sea ice remains frozen at the end of summer has decreased by more than 10% per decade since 1979.
The graph shows the average area with at least 15% sea ice on its surface each September.

verticalaxis.title: Minimum Arctic Sea Ice Extent (millions of square km)

graph.name: OceanHeat
graph.title: Ocean Heat (1022 Joules)
graph.description: Each bar shows heat energy in the top half-mile of the ocean compared to the average from 1955-2006.
graph.help: More than 90% of the warming that has occurred on Earth over the past 50 years has occurred in the ocean. The graph shows heat energy in the top 700 meters of the ocean as the difference from the average from 1955-2006.

graph.name: SunsEnergy
graph.title: Sun's Energy (W/m2)
graph.description: The sun’s energy rises and falls slightly on an 11-year cycle, with little net change over the last century.
graph.help:
Energy from the Sun varies slightly on 11-year cycles with little net change overall.
The graph shows the total amount of solar energy arriving at the top of Earth’s atmosphere.

graph.name: Glacier
graph.title: Glaciers (meters of water equivalent)
graph.description: Glaciers are shrinking: average thickness of 30 well-studied glaciers has decreased more than 40 feet since 1980.
graph.help: Since 1980, a representative set of well studied glaciers has lost the equivalent of 40 feet (12.5 meters) of water on average. The graph shows the average mass balance of 30 reference glaciers around the world.

verticalaxis.title: Cumulative Glacier Mass Balance (meters of water equivalent)

graph.name: TotalGreenhouseGas
graph.title: Heat-Trapping Gases
graph.description: The total warming effect of long-lived heat-trapping gases has gone up by 30% since 1990, the year many nations agreed to cut emissions.
graph.help: The effect of heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere has increased by 27.5% since 1990, the year many nations agreed to limit emissions under the Kyoto Protocol. The graph shows total radiative forcing from long-lived greenhouse gases as a percent change from 1990.

stat.title: % of AGGI from carbon dioxide alone

graph.name: oni
graph.title: El Niño / La Niña (Oceanic Niño Index)
graph.description: Average sea surface temperature in the Eastern Pacific Ocean indicates El Niño (yellow), La Niña (blue), or neutral (gray) conditions
graph.help: Departures from average sea surface temperature in the eastern Pacific Ocean indicate the status of the El Niño – Southern Oscillation cycle. Values greater than 0.5 indicate El Niño conditions. Values less than -0.5 indicate La Niña conditions. Values between 0.5 and -0.5 indicate neutral conditions.

graph.name: aoi
graph.title: Arctic Oscillation Index
graph.description: When this index is negative, air pressure patterns are more likely to steer severe winter storms to the eastern U.S.
graph.help: Departures from average air pressure over the Arctic region and the North Pacific and Atlantic Oceans affect the north-to-south location of the storm-steering, mid-latitude jet stream. Negative values are associated with severe winter storms in the eastern U.S.

graph.name: naoi
graph.title: North Atlantic Oscillation Index
graph.description: Air pressure patterns over the North Atlantic can steer winter weather: negative values are linked to storms in the eastern U.S.
graph.alternate: Air pressure patterns in the North Atlantic influence storm tracks. Negative values are linked with winter storms in the eastern U.S.
graph.help: Departures from average air pressure over Greenland and the central North Atlantic Ocean affect weather around the Atlantic by influencing the intensity and location of the jet stream and the storm tracks that follow it. Negative values are linked with winter storms in the eastern U.S.

graph.name: soi
graph.title: Southern Oscillation Index
graph.description: Air pressure patterns across the southern Pacific Ocean reflect El Niño (yellow), La Niña (blue), and neutral (gray) conditions.
graph.help: Differences in average air pressure at Tahiti and Darwin, Australia provide an atmospheric indicator of the El Niño–Southern Oscillation. El Niño conditions result in negative SOI values; La Niña conditions produce positive values for this index.

graph.name: pnap
graph.title: Pacific North American Pattern
graph.description: Air pressure patterns over the Pacific Ocean and North America affect the type of weather that is delivered to North America.
graph.help: Departures from average air pressure at four locations over the Pacific Ocean and North America affect the strength and location of the East Asian jet stream and the weather it delivers to North America.

graph.name: cp
graph.title: Simulation of Global Temperature
graph.legendtext: The black line shows the average of many different simulations of global temperature in the 20th century compared to average from 1971-1999, and the colored lines show projected temperature changes in the 21st century for three possible emissions scenarios. The shaded areas around each line indicate the statistical spread (one standard deviation) provided by individual model runs.
graph.help:
Results from this set of climate model experiments suggest that our planet’s average temperature could be between 2 and 9.7°F (1.1 to 5.4°C) warmer in 2100 than it is today.
The graph shows the average of temperature simulations for the 20th century (black line), followed by projected temperatures for the 21st century based on a range of emissions scenarios (colored lines). The shaded areas around each line indicate the statistical spread (one standard deviation) provided by individual model runs.
Zero on the Y-axis represents Earth’s average temperature for the period 1971-1999. For 2000-2100, the model projections differ mainly in their assumptions about the number of people on the planet and the way they use energy, and therefore, the amount of heat-trapping gas in the atmosphere.

ns0:p.ns0:span: Just as the dashboard of a car gives you a quick look at the status of your vehicle, the global climate dashboard gives you a quick look at the status of Earth’s climate system. The interactive graphs let you explore climate-relevant measurements and the relationships among them for different time periods.
Adjust the time slider, or click and drag within a graph, to change the time period displayed.
Click and drag data labels up from the list at the bottom to display their graphs.
Click the question mark next to any graph for a brief description of the parameter.
Click Read More… to access an overview article about the parameter, including a larger version of the graph and the opportunity to download the data.
